dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small caveman community made up of five large caves, al facing out towards a crackling fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slack-jawed, yet strong and confident CAVEMEN stumble abo dragging haunches of meat, pounding the dirt with sticks, dragging the women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE PAN OVER to a small cave. Not even really a cave at al but a crack in the rocks barely large enough to sleep in. Stepping out of this "cave" is a small, weak, nerdy-looki caveman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chief caveman, set apart by the large mallet he wield steps towards the fire and grunts loudly to mark the beginning of a caveman meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Loser caveman" steps forward apprehensively, only to be with laughter from the other cavemen. "Loser caveman" sig and shrinks back into his sad, little cave, watching them from the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grunting; subtitled) Me see beast today. Beast scary. Beast danger for caveman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the cavemen look nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If caveman kill beast? Caveman safe. Caveman have food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cavemen grunt in understanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who kill beast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cavemen grunt amongst themselves. The toughest of the bunch steps forward, pounds his chest and grunts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grob kill beast. Good Grob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chief notices "loser caveman" watching from a distanc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser want kill beast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the cavemen turn and laugh at the "loser caveman".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser kill nothing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the cavemen laugh hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Loser cave! So small!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser dumb!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that guy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the cavemen pick up rocks and begin throwing them at "loser caveman", who dives out of his cave and runs aroun the camp, dodging their blows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the village is asleep. Everyone, that is, but "loser caveman" who sleeps uncomfortably in his tiny litt cave, tossing and turning, unable to get comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stirring in the trees causes "loser caveman" to sit upright. There's something outside of the village. Someth big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly a GIANT TUSKED BOAR pushes through the trees and stands, looking quite menacing, not ten yards from the village fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Loser caveman" is practically shaking with fear. The boa makes eye-contact with "loser caveman" and charges direct towards his tiny little cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The giant boar runs head first into the cave opening, but opening is too small for the beast to fit its head inside "Loser caveman" screams like a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boar backs up to strike again -- this one sure to be end of "loser caveman" -- when a large boulder, knocked l by the Boar's first hit, tumbles down and lands smack on Boar's head, killing it instantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire village runs out to see what has happened. The "Loser caveman" stumbles out of the cave and dusts himsel off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chief steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beast! It dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look at loser! He almost die! Look he scared!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs. The Chief looks towards Loser, standing nervously near the corpse of the Giant Tusked Boar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser, what happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SHAMEFULLY) The Beast, it came at me. It smash my cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs hysterically. WE PAN over the many laughi faces, pointing and hooting at loser caveman's cowardice. watch as the "loser caveman's" face turns bright red, the veins in his neck pop out and his fists clench up tightly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SUDDENLY WE FLY into the caveman's skull, traveling throu his cerebral cortex and towards the frontal lobe of his small, homo erectus brain. Sparks are flying back and for across his brain as his synapses fire in rapid succession

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a SMALL EXPLOSION.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fly back out of "loser caveman's" skull -- his face contorted in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He interrupts everyone's laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on one minute!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone stops laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser wasn't finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser caveman stands up straight and tall -- all of a sud the Bruce Willis of cavemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After beast smash cave, Loser look at beast and say, "not on Loser's watch." Loser grab rock on ground, lift above head and smash it down... right onto motherfucker's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire village gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser kill beast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now fuck off, Loser going back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chief steps forward ominously, then proclaims:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser kill beast! Loser caveman hero!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser steps forward, grabs the prettiest of all cavewomen drags her towards his cave as the entire village erupts i cheer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world's first lie. A monumental occasion in the history of mankind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That lowly caveman who stumbled upon the ability to lie went on to become chief of his village, married dozens of cavewomen, and passed on the lying gene to hundreds of newborn cave-children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over time lying spread throughout the world, sparking the eventual birth of imagination itself, story- telling, religion, and the oh-so- important polite lie, as in, "Oh Patty, have you lost weight? You look fantastic."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The world would be a very different place if events had gone otherwise on that prolific, Paleolithic eve. If not for that night, man would have never acquired the ability to lie to himself and to others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A world without lying would be a world without dreams. A world without pretense. A world without fiction. A world without flattery. A world very unlike our own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The film rewinds about thirty seconds, to the point where chief asked what happened with "loser caveman" and the bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser, what happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SHAMEFULLY) The Beast, it came at me. It smash my cave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AGAIN WE FLY into the caveman's skull, traveling through homo erectus brain. Sparks are flying back and forth acro his brain as his synapses fire in rapid succession...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this time there's no explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fly back out of "loser caveman's" skull -- his face contorted in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rage slowly fades and Loser just stands there, everyo in the camp waiting for him to say something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock fall on beast. Loser do nothing. I think Loser even soil bear pants. (pause; sniffing) Loser smell bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone falls onto the ground laughing hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loser biggest loser ever! Caveman, throw rocks at loser!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the camp joins in on another round of throwin rocks at "loser caveman" as he runs around the camp, terrified and miserable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A completely indistinguishable Los Angeles mid-rent apart complex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK BELLISON pulls up in his early nineties Volvo, parks enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark (40's), average to semi-handsome, twists and turns through stucco hallways. He knocks on apartment "9C".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER MCDOOGLES opens, her face flushed. She's beautif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. You're early. I was just masturbating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes me think of your vagina. I'm Mark, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little frustrated at the moment. Also equally depressed and pessimistic about our date tonight. I'm Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope this date ends in sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me. I don't find you attractive. Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer's apartment is new-adult, as if she just found o she was an adult yet hasn't had the time or the money to complete the transition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to finish getting ready. While doing that I might realize I'm still horny and try to finish masturbating without you hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer heads towards the bathroom. Mark stands alone in living room, looking around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to her) I feel awkward and I regret being early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting back) Yeah, I'm disappointed you're early and not really looking forward to tonight in general, but the thought of being alone the rest of my life scares both my mother and I equally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's completely silent for a long beat. Mark looks around then sits on her couch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to her) I have an erection now because I assume you began masturbating once we stopped talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting to her) I'm embarrassed because I think the restaurant I've made reservations at might not be expensive enough or hip enough to impress you, but it was the best I could do because I don't make very much money. You see, I'm forty years old and have no real financial assets to speak of, I've never owned a home, and never had a significant relationship. My boss even told me today that I'm most likely going to get fired tomorrow and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer enters the room and Mark stops talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just masturbated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That makes me very horny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands up. Jennifer picks up her purse and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer drive in silence for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only doing this as a favor for my cousin Greg. He keeps begging me to go out on a date with you. He says you're funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg's a good friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we eating tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cute little place called La Bonisera in West Hollywood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You obviously don't have very much money but that's not necessarily a deal breaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have very little money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also don't really care about a guy who knows all the latest, hippest restaurants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know any of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, there are very few things in life that I care about all that much. The only things I have to offer myself or anyone else are my good looks and my affected sense of quirkiness which artistically inclined men interpret as intellect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER (cont'd) In fact, I think my best trait is the fact that I've made very few mistakes: socially, academically, financially or romantically. I take very few risks and therefore lead a relatively happy and light-hearted existence. Mostly though, I'm a kind, sweet person with the potential of genuinely becoming a vital and interesting human being the day I take the energy I expend on hyper self-reflexivity and apply it to actual action in the reality of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found that boring and started thinking about this place's fish tacos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Volvo pulls up in front of the restaurant and the val parking guy opens Jennifer's door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm extremely bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The valet parking guy hands Mark a ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the quaint Mexican restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't as nice as I remember it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to talk about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They approach the hostess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jennifer) I'm threatened by you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hostess seats them in the midst of the semi-crowded restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young, awkward waiter approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm very embarrassed that I work here. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jennifer) And you're pretty and that only makes me feel worse. Can I get you two started on some drinks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a Budweiser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll start with your Mango Margarita and probably have three more drinks by the end of the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent. (to Mark) She's out of your league.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter leaves. Jennifer and Mark peruse their menus. woman screams out from a table on the other side of the r

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SCREAMING) All of a sudden I got EXTREMELY angry!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one in the restaurant reacts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to ask you some questions about your life because that's what you do, but I'll only really listen to about half of what you're saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you spend your days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get up at eight in the morning because the noise from my alarm clock interrupts my sleep, so I lean over and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a little more specific than I expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what did you want to know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What job do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a job at an office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just typing and filing and stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you enjoy it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. But I enjoy the end result of the job which is money. And the hours are pretty good for the amount of money I make, which I spend on things I like, such as clothes, hiking, drinking -- even though I know it's bad for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER (cont'd) (PAUSE) But I'd rather just get all the money and not work for the results.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Tell me more. I'm trying to get a little insight into you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you already know a lot about me. You know I'm good looking because... well... here I am. You know I'm successful because you've seen my apartment and the clothes I'm wearing. And you know I'm happy because I'm smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer smiles brightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you always happy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Usually. Some days I stay in bed eating and crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter returns with their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands beer to Mark) Here you go. (hands drink to Jennifer) I had a sip of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you guys know what you want or do you need a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have a caesar salad with chicken because I think I'm fat but I also think I deserve something that tastes good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have the fish taco's because I had them once here and it's all I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excellent, I'll get those both started for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter leaves. Jennifer's cell phone rings from insid her purse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, one second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls out her cell phone and checks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my mother, this won't take long. Probably checking in on our date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer answers the phone. She talks openly and in plain view of Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Yes, I'm with him right now. No, not very attractive. No, doesn't make much money. He's all right though. Seems nice. Kind of funny. A bit fat. Funny little snub nose. No, I won't be sleeping with him tonight. Nope, probably not even a kiss. Okay, you too. Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't think twice. How is your mom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both of their plates are now empty. Three empty Margarita glasses sit in front of Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter approaches with the bill and places it down in middle of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jennifer) If I give you my number will you call me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks Jennifer to the front door of her apartment complex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for going on this date with me. You're way, way out of my league and I know you were just doing it as a favor to Greg, and that most likely I'll never hear from you again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I actually had a better time than I thought I'd have, but I won't know for sure how I feel about you until I'm less drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a call if you still like me once you're sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark leans in for a kiss. Jennifer kisses him on the chee and goes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for kissing me on the cheek, I know you didn't have to do that and....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer waves and heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting after her) ... you're very pretty. Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark plops into bed in his boxers. His bedroom is bland, uninspired and completely furnished by the cheapest stuff found in an IKEA catalogue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark flips on the TV and gets under the covers. A commerc comes on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man in a suit stands next to a single can of coke resti on a small table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I'm Jim and I'm the spokesperson for the Coca-Cola company. I'm here today to ask you to continue buying coke. I'm sure it's a drink you've been drinking for years, and if you still enjoy it, I'd like to remind you to buy it again sometime soon. It's basically just brown sugar water, we haven't changed the ingredients much lately, so there's nothing new about it I can say. We changed the can around a little bit. See, the colors here are a little different, and we even put a polar bear on it for the kids. Also, coke is very high in sugar, can lead to obesity in children and adults who don't sustain a healthy diet, and has a Ph acidity level high enough to dissolve teeth and bones over extended periods of time. Coke also works great at removing corrosion from car batteries and loosening rusted bolts. So that's it, it's coke. Everyone knows it. It's very famous. I'm Jim, I work for coke, and I'm asking you to not stop buying coke. That's all. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: Coke logo with tagline: "It's Coke. It's very famous."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark falls asleep with the TV on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's alarm clock blares. Groggily he rises and sighs deeply. He has nothing to look forward to today. Or any d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands in his building's elevator. The doors open an FRANK, mid-forties and bald, enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Mark. How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so good. Last night I went on a date with a girl I've had a crush on for years who will most likely never call me again and I'm pretty sure I'm going to get fired today. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spent the whole night throwing up pain killers because I'm too afraid to take enough to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The elevator doors open on the lobby. Mark nods at Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mark drives to work we take in a bit of his world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homeless man stands on a street corner with a sign that reads: "I don't understand why I'm homeless and all of yo are not."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A business man talking loudly into his cell phone pulls u next to mark at a red light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to anyone on my cell phone. I only want people to assume I'm very busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At another red light Mark eavesdrops on a couple having a loud argument in front of a coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I woke up this morning and realized that, not only do I not love you, but that the thought of touching you sickens me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more you hate me the more I fall in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Bus passes in front of Mark's car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: The bus ad simply shows a can of Pepsi, and rea "Pepsi. When they don't have Coke."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car honks behind Mark. The man leans out of his car and yells at Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it, fatty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark drives forward, waving to the man apologetically as man zooms past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark parks his car and walks towards a large office build The sign on the building reads: "LECTURE FILMS MOTION PIC STUDIOS -- We Film Someone Telling You About Things That Happened."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In front of the building is a man in a suit standing on h briefcase with his tie around his head, screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't natural! None of this is natural! We're all animals! This doesn't feel right! Why am I wearing clothes? How can you people live like this? Where did all this concrete come from?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks right by him. A woman in a business suit stops on his way through the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go in there today. I just don't. You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark nods understandingly and enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Mark walks through the lobby we get a brief glimpse of some of the movie posters lining the wall: "The Holocaust "The Death of the Dinosaurs", "Napoleon", "The Civil War"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each poster shows a different austere man sitting in a ch holding a script in his lap, with a title above his head. posters are extremely boring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tour guide leads a row of tourists through the lobby. A Mark enters we overhear the tour guide's speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of Lecture Films' productions are written, filmed and edited right here on this very lot. In fact, this building is where Lecture Films' talented writers scour through the world's past events, searching for the most entertaining, dramatic and even hilarious moments of world history, which are then turned into scripts, handed over to our world-famous Readers, and filmed for your viewing pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole tour "oohs". The tour guide walks over towards large flat-screen television embedded into the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you'll just follow me over to this monitor you'll get a sneak peak at Lecture Film's upcoming summer's blockbuster: "Napoleon 1812 to 1813."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone "oohs" again. Mark, curious as well, stops to wa the trailer with the tour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: TV SCREEN. A black screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming this summer from Lecture Films Motion Picture Studios. Written by Oscar winning screenwriter Rob Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT Mark scowling at this name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And starring Oscar winning Reader Nathan Goldfrappe, comes the epic sequel to last year's most talked about film: "Napoleon 1810 to 1811". Prepare for the adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black fades to NATHAN GOLDFRAPPE, a middle-aged auste man sitting before a fire in a velvet smoking jacket, hol a script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) And so Napoleon invaded Russia with a brute force of nearly seven hundred thousand men behind him armed with muskets and supported by canon brigades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Learn of his defeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) Through the devastating snow they marched, crippled by disease and hunger, Napoleon's men marched on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to his redemption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT the tour, enraptured by this trailer. A few of t tourists whisper to each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love these films. Saves me reading the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INTERCUT the trailer title slamming onto the screen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Napoleon 1812 to 1813. Coming this summer from Lecture Films.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trailer ends and the tour applauds. The tour guide tu to find Mark walking away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look everyone, there goes Mark Bellison, one of Lecture Films very own screenwriters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole tour turns towards Mark. Mark turns around and dejectedly waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's one of our least successful writers here at Lecture Films. (PAUSE) I also hear he's most likely getting fired today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tour nods at Mark. Mark nods back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now let's head to editing bay where we can watch....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks past cubicle after cubicle until he comes to h office and SHELLEY, his attractive late-20's receptionist

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Shelley. I'm still attracted to you today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Mark. Everyday I realize more and more how over-qualified I am for this position and how incompetent you are at yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any messages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony's coming by within the hour to see if he can work up the courage to fire you. If he can't, he said he'll definitely do it tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody else called? No calls to do with actual work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I told everybody you were getting fired this week and not to expect their calls returned, so no one left any messages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I'd rather you took down the messages just in case I don't get fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're almost definitely getting fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it hasn't happened yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, but everybody knows you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll be in my office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll be searching for new jobs on Craigslist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's office is completely boring and unremarkable, much like his apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock on his door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANTHONY enters, looking very much the boss in his expensi suit, yet nervous and fearful as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, you look really depressed today. That's going to make this so much harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, don't fire me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony sits down on the other side of Mark's desk and le forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, the 1300's are boring. Nothing interesting happened in that century. Nobody cares about the post-Roman, pre-enlightenment era. The last few scripts you turned in were depressing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were about the black plague! It's the 1300's Anthony, what else am I going to write about!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not totally your fault, Mark. You got stuck with a bad century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I can make it work!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it up Mark, it's not like something new is going to have happened in the 1300's. At Lecture Films we're no longer interested in searching through the less well- known historical periods for great events, we just want to take the big name Reader's of the day and have them read the historical events that people know and love: the holocaust, D-day, the birth of electricity. These are the stories people want to see, because they know them. They find comfort in them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony pauses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I could come back and do this tomorrow? I just got very nervous about firing you. I don't do well with confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anyway you could do it now? I'd rather not put it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony thinks for a moment, struggling to find the coura

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (MEEKLY) You're fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony slinks out of the room. Mark looks down at his computer to see he has an email in his inbox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON: MARK'S COMPUTER -- The email reads: "I woke up morning, sober, and realized that, while I did enjoy your company, based on your looks, your financial situation an your position in life, I have no interest in you romantically. I'm just too far out of your league. --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits back in his chair and sighs deeply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a really good writer, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all of his meager belongings stuffed into a box, Mar leaves his office, stopping in front of Shelley's desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I loathed almost every minute I worked for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I often fantasized about you naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea. But I have very little hope for the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have much hope for you either, but I wish you good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Shelley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark heads towards the elevator and is stopped by ROB MARLOWE, a little weasel man with a hip haircut and expen clothes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they fucking fired you, huh dipshit? I always knew the Black Plague would never work as a movie. Guess the 1300's were as much of a loser as you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't make me feel worse. Or actually whatever, go ahead, I don't think I could possibly feel worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I fucking always hated you. You're a shitty writer assigned to a shitty century and you're a little man bitch. But I was always threatened by you because I knew there was something different about you that I didn't understand and I fucking hate things I don't understand. But you will always be a loser and I will always be more successful than you in nearly every way. That's just the way it is. And Shelley calls you an ass fag behind your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, now I feel worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob storms off. Mark slinks into the elevator and hangs h head in shame as the doors close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark enters the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks up to the front desk to find a young reception

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you looking to abandon an elderly person?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already have. Martha Bellison. I'm her grandson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooh, it's good you're here. She's not doing well. You should say your final goodbyes today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say that every time I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's at the top of our death pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks down the hall, passing different elderly peopl who reach out to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like my dead son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life gets worse with each passing minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on pills that make everything orange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark opens a door and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An elderly woman in a light blue robe sits on the side of bed, with her back to Mark, staring at the wall only inch from her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh Grandma, that is so depressing. Come on, at least stare at the ceiling or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes his grandmother by the hand and steers her to other side of her bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television is broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television isn't broken. You probably sat on the remote and changed it to channel two again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark flicks on the TV with the remote. Static fills the screen. He changes the channel and a picture comes into v

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, you had it on the wrong channel. It needs to be on channel three in order for the satellite to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand anything you just said and that makes me scared and angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't understand what it feels like to be you so it just irritates me and makes me think you're stupid. But I also love you and wish things were better for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma, I lost my job today. I'm forty years old. I'm completely alone and I've got absolutely no prospects for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mark. Things aren't any better for me here. I can't afford most of my medication, I'm very alone and I forget more and more every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just so tired of life. Why does life have to be so... what's the word? Don't you sometimes wish you could change things? Don't you sometimes wish you weren't such a loser?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I'm a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you're a loser, grandma. Our family is made up of losers. We're all poor, we're all average looking, we're all only moderately intelligent, we're all lonely and unloved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're poor because we weren't born with money and it's very hard to make enough money in a single lifetime to move from one social class to another. We're only moderately intelligent because there's been a lot of inbreeding in our lineage. And we're only lonely and unloved right now. Remember, I've had two husbands I loved very much in my lifetime. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHA (cont'd) And maybe one day you'll have a wife that you love very much too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but I'm not talking about the past, Grandma. I'm talking about right now. And right now we're both losers, Grandma. We're both shitty, shitty losers. Don't you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose we are. But things could be worse. We could be homeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd rather be dead than be homeless. That's why I need to get out there and find a job. If I have to be homeless, I'm going to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that's sad. I love you, Mark. Good luck finding a job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too, Grandma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark leaves. As he shuts the door from the hallway he hea the channel change and turn back to static.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and his friend GREG (40'S), an even less attractive, less interesting and less intelligent version of Mark, ar bellied up the bar with half empty beers in front of them

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll start looking for a job tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lately I don't like Indian people. (PAUSE) I don't like white people even more though. I fucking hate white people. I fucking hate people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, thanks for setting me up with your cousin by the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third cousin. She's hot right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way out of your league. Dunno why you bothered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It felt nice to go out with someone that pretty. Like for just one moment I experienced what it would be like to be the type of person someone like that would date. It felt good. Doesn't matter anyway. I will always be just who I am right now: average looking, of average intelligence with an average personality. Just a completely generic human being.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your life is still better than mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By a good margin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sad beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lately I've been crying in my sleep and waking up in a pool of urine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really wish I had a better friend than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what are you going to do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Guess I'll start looking for another crappy job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doubt you'll find one. Not much need for an out-of-work writer specializing in the Black Plague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark downs his last shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to go now. You're seriously depressing me. I really wish I was cool enough to have a better friend than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the best you're gonna get, man. Call me later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gets up and drunkenly stumbles out of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark drunkenly lies in bed. He picks up the phone and dia

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark just breathes, too scared to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? I can hear you breathing. Is this a rapist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (QUICKLY) No, it's Mark. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hangs up quickly, embarrassed and ashamed. He sighs turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The alarm clock goes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut the fuck up, I don't even have a job!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tosses the alarm clock across the room and goes back bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud banging wakes Mark who groggily stumbles out of be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark opens the door to find his landlord, a middle aged, groomed man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here for the rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was going to come talk to you about that. I got fired yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. That's why I'm here for the rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I haven't got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much do you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've got about three hundred dollars in my bank account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rent is eight hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I haven't got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're evicted. I'll help you with your things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A stunned Mark stands helpless as the Landlord pushes pas him, grabs a lamp from his living room and carries it out into the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me with the couch. It looks heavy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sighs and follows the Landlord back into his apartme

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With all of his belongings piled up in the hallway, a tir and sweaty Mark stares defeatedly at his landlord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have one day to get your things out of this hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I supposed to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got three hundred dollars. Rent a truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fuck me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark grits his teeth in rage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark steps up to the female teller at the bank. Mark is a the lowest point in his entire life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I help you today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to make a withdrawal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, sir. I'm confident I can help you with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just been evicted from my apartment so I need to withdraw what I have left in my account so I can move my things out. I guess I need to close out my account to do that. (PAUSE) I think I'm about to be homeless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON MARK: This sinks in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately sir the system is down right now so I'm not going to be able to perform an account closure until the system is back up. But I can assist you in a withdrawal. How much would you like to withdraw?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like to withdraw eight hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank teller smiles at Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much are you going to withdraw today, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of it. Just whatever is left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The system is down, sir. Please tell me how much you have in your account?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the peak of his despair something suddenly comes over Mark. His face turns a light shade of red as the wheels b to spin in his brain. He is fighting something within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE FLY into Mark's skull, traveling through his cerebral cortex and towards the frontal lobe of his brain. Sparks flying back and forth across his brain as his synapses fi in rapid succession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a small explosion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We fly back out of Mark's skull -- his eyes are locked on Bank Teller's like a deer in the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awkwardly fast) Eight hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more confident) I have eight hundred dollars in my bank account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teller locks eyes with Mark... then looks towards her computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second here. The system just came back up. (to co-worker) System seems to be back up, guys. (to Mark) Just one second while I access your account. You said you're withdrawing eight hundred, correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark breaks out in a cold sweat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bank teller types on her keyboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, look at this. It says here you've only got three hundred dollars in your account. But you said you wanted to withdraw eight hundred?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark doesn't know what to say. He tries to speak but noth comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize for this sir, but it seems our system has made a mistake. Hold on one second while I go and get your eight hundred dollars. Did you want that in large or small bills?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gulps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Large bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The teller walks away. Mark looks around nervously, awkwa smiling at the other tellers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to co-worker) Guys the computers seem to be a bit buggy. Will someone call James to come in and look into it, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moments later the Bank Teller returns and begins counting eight hundred dollars for Mark. Mark stares at the money wide eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are. Eight hundred dollars. Anything else I can do for you today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In shock, Mark shakes his head. The bank teller smiles bi him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes our computers can get a bit buggy, especially when the system goes down. Sorry for any inconvenience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes his money and hurriedly walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bursting out of the bank, Mark is a caveman who just inve fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark knocks on his LANDLORD'S door. A short, stodgy old m opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark holds out a wad of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paying my rent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The landlord looks at the money and slowly reaches out to take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get this money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was amazing. I went in to the bank and the system was down and I was going to take out three hundred dollars but she asked me how much I'd like to take out and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stops himself. Something else takes over within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found it. Lying on the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Landlord and Mark both lock eyes for a tense beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me my key back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark jumps around his apartment, dancing and screaming. M is a caveman who just invented sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today I stumbled upon something no man has ever stumbled upon before. What I have done today they will write about in history books for generations to come. And yet, only moments ago... it was unfathomable not only to myself, but to mankind as a whole. What I have found there is no word for. And it was as simple as... (long pause) ... how do I explain this... (long pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg sit at the bar, Greg half listening as an inspired Mark ends his monologue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I said something... that wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg perks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said something... that... wasn't. I... what's the word I'm looking for? Well, there is no word. Of course there's not, I just invented it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is frustrated by his inability to explain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Watch. (calling over bartender) Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JIM, mid-40's, short and stout, waddles over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, stands up, clears his throat, and holds his hands o like "gimme some room".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a long pause as Mark summons his newfound talent:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (PROFOUNDLY) My name is Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg and Jim look at Mark confusedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dead serious) Your name is Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without hesitation) Hi Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It amazes me that I never knew your real name. (PAUSE) Doug is good. It suits you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on guys. Are you serious? What's my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. My name is Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still dead serious) Your name is Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still without hesitation) Hi Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark suits you much better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark-o.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys aren't following me. (THINKING) Okay, guys...I'm black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very light skinned, but I can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted a black friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark punches the bar in anger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck it, I'm an Eskimo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen a black Eskimo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'm a pirate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know they still had those.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a dangerous pirate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then, I'm a lion tamer... and I have purple hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you scared you'll get bitten one day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Greg) I want to die my hair purple just like Mark's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg nods. Mark sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits at the bar looking completely bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a one-armed Jewish space explorer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When's your launch date?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shalom. How'd you lose your arm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I invented the bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you get me a discount on a ten speed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sighs, finishes his beer and gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I give up. And I'm bored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark heads towards the door, dejected. He turns back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, if you had the power to make things the way you wanted them, what would you do first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could do anything in the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything at all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg and Jim think this over long and hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd bone bitches asses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right in the ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Specifically the ass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could change things I would make all the hot chicks bone me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agreed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark mulls this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright then, let's try that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark downs his beer and heads towards the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks the street, a hunter looking for his prey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Within seconds Mark spots a gorgeous blonde walking right towards him. He stops in his track, quickly trying to dec how best to proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But as the blonde passes him he just stares at her like a deer in the headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at me, I'm not attracted to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde walks away. Mark stands on the sidewalk starin off into space, the wheels in his mind working overtime. it hits him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't bother. I've heard it all before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BLURTING) THE WORLD IS GOING TO END IF WE DON'T HAVE SEX RIGHT NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immediately the blonde's eyes well up in tears. She is terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do we have time to get to a motel or do we have to do it right here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is a caveman who just invented his penis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The neon sign outside reads "A Cheap Motel for Intercours with a Near Stranger".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We slowly PUSH IN on the door of room 206. We hear noises inside that at first sound like moaning, but as we get closer... they sound more like crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bawling her eyes out and sitting on the bed doing her bes get her shoes off, is the hot blonde.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits across from her, a look of guilt and revulsion his face. This is not what he expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BAWLING) I'm sorry, I'm just so scared. I don't want the world to end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLONDE (cont'd) I don't want to die in this motel room. I think I'm going to throw up. Help me get my pants off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands up. The blonde grabs him and pulls him toward her. He pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This isn't right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde screams and drops to her knees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! We have to have sex! The world is going to end! Think of the children and little babies!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks down at this panicked, helpless girl and feels really, really bad about himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just calm down for one second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks over to the phone and picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I be calm? The world might end any second! DON'T YOU UNDERSTAND?! WE'RE ALL GOING TO DIE!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone) Hello... NASA? Yes, it's... me. Oh, good. That's very good news. Good news indeed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hangs up the phone. The blonde is rocking back and f on the bed in a fetal position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to be okay. The world isn't going to end. Everyone is going to be fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde tackles him in a bear hug, sobbing and laughin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WE'RE GOING TO LIVE! We're going to live! Thank you! Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde falls onto the bed in exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This has been the worst... and the best... day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, please stay. We've been through so much together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at this helpless girl for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde's face and mood do an instant 180.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SPITEFUL) Well, I hate assholes. Get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blonde chucks her shoes at Mark as he closes the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks across the parking lot. A look of total shock his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg is in the exact same position Mark left him in, but twice as drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark plops down next to him, dazed and upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was one of the worst experiences of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SHIT-FACED) Did you invent a new kind of bike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else would you do if you could do anything in the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bone chicks asses. That's what I'd do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else though. What's the second thing you'd do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg nods off. Mark nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else would you do, dipshit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd get money. I'd get all the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg passes out. Mark nods his head, takes the three full shots sitting in front of Greg and does them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Let's do that. Greg, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going on a trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg immediately perks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg is driving, Mark rides shotgun, both of them are completely plastered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks for driving man, I'm completely plastered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just as hammered as you. But I don't care if I get arrested. I'm trying to hit bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHOOP-WHOOP come the flashing lights of a cop car right behind them. Greg begins to pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes bottom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks worried. The cop comes to Greg's window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing safer than pulling over two nerdy white guys in their forties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're going to jail. Blow in here, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop pulls out a Breathalyzer and holds it up to Greg' mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, officer. Don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think you can afford my bribe, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much does it cost to bribe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least five grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that's high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to feel that I've got some sense of integrity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg blows in the Breathalyzer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, that's off the charts. Step out of the car, son. You're drunk and going to jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. (PAUSE) He's not drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg stumbles and falls, passing out in the dirt. The cop stares at Mark for a long beat while his brain wraps arou this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cop bangs his Breathalyzer against his leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn thing must be broken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the background we can hear Greg vomiting profusely. Th cop picks up Greg and puts him back in the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Greg) Son, you might want to drive yourself to the nearest hospital. You have food poisoning or some kind of flu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is basically passed out, vomit drooling down his chi He couldn't look more drunk. The cop and Mark stare at hi for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mark) Maybe you oughta drive, son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Driving away with Greg in the passenger seat, a giant smi comes across Mark's face as he begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was awesome!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop laughing, I'm sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna be all right, Greg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg vomits all over himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stupid stomach flu. (PAUSE) Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas, baby. Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pulls in front of the Bellagio hotel and casino. Bot Mark, and a very hungover looking Greg, pop out of the ca Mark hands the keys to the valet and they both stumble inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Bellagio. We've all been there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we doing here? We don't have any money to throw away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pulls out a small wad of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that, a few hundred bucks? That's not going to last us very long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg step up to the chip counter. Mark slides hi small wad through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chips please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHIP WOMAN looks at his money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a very good chance you'll lose all this money here tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And even if you do happen to win, there's an even better chance that in the long run we'll win it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some of the games are fixed. Like all the ones that use computers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman slides him a short stack of chips. Greg frowns. Mark and Greg walk towards the tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg look around. A cocktail waitress approaches

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could be a stripper I would, but I'm not attractive enough. Drinks, guys?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I have a stomach flu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll both have beers and we'll take them at that roulette table over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark points to a table and walks away. The waitress nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh come on, roulette is the stupidest game of them all. It's pure chance, no skill whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. I'm feeling lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've never had a lucky day in your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They arrive at the roulette table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your bets in, get your bets in. The house always wins in the long run. Because of the zero's on the board every bet is slightly favored towards the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark puts his chips down on seventeen black. The dealer starts the wheel. The ball comes to a stop on twenty-seve red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-seven red. No one wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In full view, Mark slides his chips over to twenty-seven

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on twenty-seven red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dealer looks at this. His brain takes a moment to respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a winner. Congratulations, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dealer stacks up Mark's new chips and pushes them ove him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it. You just, like, quadrupled your money. You lucky son of a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nothing. Watch this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark puts all of his chips on double zero. A bunch of oth people scatter their chips around the table as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get your bets in, get your bets in. The house always wins in the long run. Fork over your money right here folks. I say this so often I want to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dealer spins the ball. It comes to a halt on nine bla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine black. No winners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes ALL of the chips on the table, both his and EVERYONE ELSE'S and slides them together into a giant pil and sits them right on nine black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on nine black. These are all mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The table cheers for Mark. Some people are a bit confused and a slight hubbub arises in the background: "I thought had chips on the table." "Yeah, me too." "We must be drun "That guys is lucky!" Even the dealer looks a bit confuse but gets over it quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nine black wins. Big winner. Congratulations, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roulette dealer slides about five grand in chips over Mark. Greg's jaw is on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark notices the confused people around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I should. Lets go play slots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is talking to a Pit Man right in front of a slot machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, I just won a major jackpot on this slot machine but no money came out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry about that, sir. Let me get that fixed for you. And can I say congratulations, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pit Man whispers a few words into his lapel mic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg, each carrying four giant buckets overflowi with chips, waddle through the casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the most amazing night of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg lounge around the Bellagio penthouse suite, piles of chips and cash lying around them. Greg is pacing delightedly. Mark lies on the couch, unsatisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It amazes me the winning streak you're on. You must be the luckiest man in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, sort of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was like we couldn't lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We couldn't lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a system?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, with your system in just a few weeks I figure we could be the richest people in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's what I'm thinking. We take all the money in the world... and put it on black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why put it on black? Why stop there? Put it on a number and get thirty five times back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg's eyes widen at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly what we'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on, I think I found a flaw in your plan. How can they pay us if we have all the money in the world?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they'd just have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they can't because we've got it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they'd better find it. They can't let us bet if they're not going to pay us back. They'll have to just give us the casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We already own the casino. We've got all the money in the world. We'll be betting against ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we'll go to another casino.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We own that one too. We won that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we own all the casino's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if we win we can't pay us back because we already have all the money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg thinks this over for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only one thing we can do then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take ourselves into the back room and break our own fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, exhausted from his long night, waits for the elevat to arrive. The elevator doors open and Frank, the depress neighbor, steps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey there, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark. How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty good, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank stops and turns around, this is a different respons

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awful. I was doing some internet research last night about suffocation suicide. I'm probably going to give that a try tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (PAUSE) All right. Bye, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gets in the elevator, Frank walks away. A short beat Mark exits the elevator and yells after Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, halfway out the building, turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? I'm miserable. And no one will care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a loser, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do it, Frank. Things are going to be all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You're going to meet someone soon. You won't be so lonely. Things are going to turn around at your job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My job's actually fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, things are going to get better. Better than they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the depression?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It will go away very soon. You're going to be happy soon, Frank. You just need to wait for it. Listen to me: you don't need to kill yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something changes in Frank. A slight smile comes over him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. Man, and that suffocation thing really seemed like a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Well, my night's open now. You want to hang out later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank's smile fades a tiny bit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Of course. Let's hang out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you after work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gets back in the elevator to the sound of Frank laug to himself as he exits the building. We hold on Mark for moment as he smiles and nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits at kitchen table, pen and paper in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
