dialogues.text: (WRITING) I've discovered something today very important... and very powerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark doing various good deeds throughout the day. V.O pla throughout.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Marks walks up to the homeless man with the "I don't understand why I'm homeless and you are all not" sign. He says something to the homeless man, who quickly drops his sign and follows Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm as excited as I've ever been in my entire life, and equally scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK (V.O.) (cont'd) I'm writing this down in a letter in case this thing I've discovered somehow ends up killing me. I want to ensure that, even if I wasn't strong enough to use it, that my invention doesn't once again disappear, never to be discovered again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and the homeless man are at the bank. Mark is talkin the bank teller. The homeless man looks at Mark nervously The teller leaves and comes back with stacks and stacks o cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In just a few hours since I stumbled upon my discovery I have seen its potential for evil and I have seen its potential for good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside Lecture Films, Mark talks to the woman who was adamant about not wanting to go to work. He whispers a fe words into her ear. She smiles, picks up her briefcase an gladly walks into work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must be careful with my discovery, for at this point I barely understand it, let alone think I have the power to control it. All I know is that if I'm not careful I could easily do irreparable damage to the world, or even cause my own premature death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks up to the arguing couple at the coffee shop, w are now sitting at different tables, not even looking at other. He pulls up a chair next to each of them, individually, and says a few words to them. Within moment the two of them are running into each other's arms and ma out passionately on the floor of the coffee shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, to explain my invention. In essence, my creation is the act of saying words that simply are not. For example, if I tell someone that my eyes are blue, then it simply becomes fact. I still know that, indeed, my eyes are brown, but no one else is aware of this fact, so therefore I have blue eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK (V.O.) (cont'd) It's a game of numbers: there is only one of me who knows I have brown eyes, and so many of them who do not. The numbers always win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is at the elderly home, walking the halls and whispe to his grandmother and each elderly person he passes, lea each one of them with a smile upon their faces, and some tears streaming down their cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever is reading this, go ahead and try it. Tell someone your eyes are a different color then they are. I think you'll be amazed at the results. It's so simple and yet... so powerful... this thing I've invented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Frank are watching TV in Mark's apartment. The t of them are drinking beers and having a good time watchin television.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Au Revoir, future reader, au revoir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark signs his letter, seals it in an envelope, writes "M INVENTION" on the outside of it and sticks it in a drawer his kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark lies in bed watching TV. He picks up the phone and dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer. It's Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna hang up on me again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Maybe. Who knows. I'm calling because I want to ask you out on another date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I discovered something yesterday. I found out I can pretty much have my life anyway I want it from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. I gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, and I know you said you didn't want to date me ever again, but I'm different now. Things have changed. I think I'm in your league now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're better looking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I'm not better looking. I'm just more... powerful. I think you have to see it for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you been to the gym?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I haven't been to the gym. It's just... it's amazing. Things are different for me now. You have to see this. I think you'll hardly recognize me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you buy better clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, look can we just meet up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence on the other end of the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer, If there was even a glimmer of something about me that you liked, please say yes. You even admitted that we got along well. Just give me one more chance. Just one little teensy, tiny date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantastic. Tomorrow night. I'll pick you up at eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most likely it'll be our last date though, so just know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SARCASTIC) That's very sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it wasn't. Did you not hear what I said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, no I was being... (pause; searching) ...there's no word for it. See you tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hangs up happily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Our World.... in the 1800's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAN ON TV: The screen is all black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... came the greatest revolution of them all. (climactic music) The Industrial Revolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black fades to ANGELO BADSMITH, a middle-aged African American man sitting before a fire in a green smoking jac holding a script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Written by famed screenwriter Rob Marlowe and read by Oscar winning Reader Angelo Badsmith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm Angelo Badmsith. Come watch me read about the exciting events that took place during the Industrial Revolution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGELO BADSMITH (cont'd) Also, I will tell you all about my personal misfortunes, such as my wife who cheated on me with a man named Perry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen reads: "The Industrial Revolution. Summer `07.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK ON MARK: His eyes are wide. The wheels in his head a spinning again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob Marlowe, your streak of success has finally come to an end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Mark jumps and runs to his kitchen table. He gra pen, pulls out a sheet of paper... and begins writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF JUMP CUTS: Mark writing furiously throughout th night, piling up page upon page. By the time the sun come Mark is exhausted, with barely the energy to keep his hea as he writes "the end" and places the final page on his l stack of finished pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hustles through the parking lot, manuscript in hand. reaches the door and then stops -- remembering something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark runs to the curb and throws his manuscript onto the dirty, filthy street. He gets down on his hands and knees rubs his manuscript into the grime, making sure to get ev page equally filthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satisfied, he organizes the pages into a neat pile and en Lecture Films.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks the aisles of Lecture Films. People stop to st at him. There is a whispered hubbub from the many cubicle and offices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark passes his old office, stopping to read the sign on door: "14TH CENTURY -- CLOSED."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark grimaces and keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone crazy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark turns his head to see Shelley, standing down the hal terrified, staring at Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark ignores her and keeps walking. Leaning against his d jamb, is Rob, smirking as Mark passes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come to beg for your old job back? Hey everybody, here's the loser who thought the Black Plague would make for an interesting film. Good luck, douche bag. Freaking loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks right up to the door that reads, "Head of Development -- Anthony James."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony is on the phone, his back to Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to fire me any moment, I just know it. I'm really, really horrible at my job. I don't know anything about movies. I don't even like movies. I like sports. Head of development, what does that even mean? I'm not a smart person. Okay, talk to you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony turns around to find Mark. His face becomes very, very scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the head of the studio. (PAUSE) I'm very scared that you're mad at me about the whole firing thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not mad at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony is relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh good, because I feel really bad about it. I mean, I would be horrible at your job too. I would be horrible at any job in this place. (PAUSE) I love sports.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both stare at each other for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pulls up a chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you fired me, I was very depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so I left this building and I just started walking. And I walked all the way out of town. And then I walked into the desert and I fell asleep under a tree.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't do well with other people's life changing events.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when I woke up I found this strange old chest sticking out of the ground. So I started digging. And I unearthed a very old and ancient box. Probably, oh... about... seven hundred years old. And inside the box... (holding up manuscript) ... was this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark places his muddy, dirty, manuscript down on Anthony' desk. Anthony is scared to touch it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a never-before-heard historical event from the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When does it take place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 1300's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The excitement drains from Anthony's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you we're not interested in Black Plague movies here, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one isn't about the black plague. Well it isn't just about the black plague. Let me read you some of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony rolls his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony, get excited about this. This is a brand new event from history that no one has ever heard before. It's a great human discovery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but is there a movie there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The greatest movie Lecture Films has ever made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark picks up the manuscript and opens the first page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) On the very first day of the fourteenth century, a momentous occasion occurred. It began as a day much like any other. The sun rose, the people awoke, workers began to work, babies began to cry. But all of that was interrupted when a giant flying space ship crashed down from the skies and landed in the heart of Babylon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony's mouth drops to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark smiles. Anthony picks up his phone and presses "intercom".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want everyone in here now! We've got a BIG ONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anthony hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Mark. Continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) As the smoke cleared, the door to the spaceship opened and inside, were hundreds of beautiful, half naked alien women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with people now, all of them hanging o every word Mark reads from his manuscript. Even Rob and Shelly lean against the back wall, their minds blown by t story Mark is telling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) And then the ninja army unleashed a giant fireball that brought the robot dinosaur to its knees, saving Mars, Earth and the Nude Amazonian Alien Women all in one sweeping motion. The earth was saved. Jebediah and Aleena were allowed to marry by alien king Xardon. It was to be the First Human-Nude Amazonian Alien Woman wedding, and no expenses would be spared. All of Babylon and Mars were invited to join in the celebrations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People around the room wipe tears from their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) The wedding was held on a brisk summers day on Mars, with all of the survivors of the Great Ninja War and the Black Plague present. They feasted and danced and laughed and it was a joyous occasion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK (cont'd) The moment the bride and groom kissed, King Xardon performed a mind-wipe on all of the humans, thereby erasing all knowledge of these events from their minds, and sent them back to Babylon. For seven hundred years these events would be forgotten by mankind until one day, a great writer by the name of Mark Bellison, would stumble upon them in the desert, after being fired by his shit boss Anthony and mocked by Rob and Shelly, two huge douche bags. Lecture Films Motion Picture Studios would go on to make the picture and it would be a big success, and Mark would become very wealthy and famous from it. The End.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire room bursts into applause. Not just normal applause, but massive, epic applause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone crowds around Mark, hugging him, touching him, b away by the magnanimity of the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, tell us what it's called.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark thinks it over for a moment and looks right at Rob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Rob) The Black Plague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob sneers. Everyone "aahs" and claps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer sit at a candlelit table in the corner hip and fancy restaurant. Jennifer looks beautiful. Mark on cloud nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations on selling your script today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Thank you for having dinner with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone needs to eat. (PAUSE) And I enjoy your company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark smiles. They both sip their drinks and look at their menus. The waiter comes up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an extremely important waiter. (PAUSE) What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to know what it is, I just want to order the most expensive thing on the menu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have the duck. And I think you look like a little rat faced man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll have those right up for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter leaves. Mark and Jennifer stare at each other a short beat. Something has changed between them and they both feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things seem to be turning around for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today is the best day of my life. Hands down. Easy. Best day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not every day you unearth a monumental historical event and sell it for a ton of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wasn't the best part. It was great, but it wasn't the peak of my day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had a crush on you ever since I saw a picture of you on Greg's refrigerator two years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The best part of my day today is right now, sitting at this table here with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the most beautiful woman I've ever seen in my life, and you're special... and it makes me happy to be around you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer is touched...but she doesn't reciprocate Mark's feelings. Jennifer moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something about your family. I really don't know much about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, my family. We're what you'd probably call "not lucky". My whole family is kind of marked by tragedy, bad luck and general... shittiness. It goes back a long ways and could probably drive someone to suicide just hearing about it, so I'll keep it simple. My mom died when I was six. Cancer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And my dad got real depressed and lost his job. Out of work and with a kid to raise he had no choice but to turn to a life of crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of crime?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a robber. Houses mostly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice, mid-to-upper class home. Lots of white wood. The ho is very quiet, until... the phone rings and the answer machine picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on answer machine) Hi, I'm calling to let you know I'll be robbing your house today. I'll probably be there within the hour. (PAUSE) I hope you're not there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The message ends. PAN OVER to a SOCCER MOM standing in th doorway. She drops her coffee and screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was a very unlucky man. He spent his last days behind bars. I never really knew him. (sad moment; pause) But I guess I've also had a little luck in my life. I did have a wonderful grandmother who raised me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, she's great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old person's home obviously. Who wants to live with that? Gross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm going to get her out of there tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK (cont'd) I'm going to buy her a big beautiful mansion where she can spend her few remaining days in luxury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter arrives with their food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what's wrong with the chef today, but these just look awful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He places them down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look fine to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer begin eating. Mark wants to say somethi and takes a moment to summon the courage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. I was thinking that since I'm going to be rich and successful now that I might be in your league. (PAUSE) And that maybe we could be together. Romantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would be the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark didn't expect this answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I don't know, maybe we might enjoy it. Maybe we'd be good together and could have a happy life, raise a family together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I do like you. And I enjoy your company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JENNIFER (cont'd) And if we were to get together and procreate I would like the offspring that are carrying half my genetic code to be well taken care of and financially stable. I also think you'd make a good father and a good husband, which I like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark smiles. This is going well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, none of that changes the fact that you'd still be contributing half of the genetic code to our children. (PAUSE) I don't want short, fat kids with little snub noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the end of that. Mark nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes a bite of his food. Jennifer smiles and does t same, oblivious to Mark's pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's cell phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (PAUSE) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's face melts in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (LOUDLY) WHAT?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark bursts into the hospital room to find his grandmothe MARTHA looking tired and scared, hooked up to dozens of machines, the heart monitor beeping ominously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma, they just called me. What's going on? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I fell on my way back to my room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do the doctors say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say I'll probably die tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock on the door. The doctor enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hello. I was just coming in to check on her, you must be Martha Bellison's grandson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about she's going to die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. It just doesn't look good. She's suffered a major heart attack and her heart is very weak, her pulse not very strong, her blood pressure is dropping rapidly and most likely she'll have a fatal heart attack during the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor checks Martha's chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup, still going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits down next to Martha, in total shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, guys. I wish I felt something for you two, but I really don't. I do this exact thing about thirty times a night and it's really hardened me to human suffering. On a side note, it's fajita night at the cafeteria downstairs. You might think about grabbing a bite to eat there after your grandma dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doctor leaves. Mark holds his grandmother's hand, her hand is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so scared, Mark. I don't want to die. You know, people don't talk about it much, but death is a horrible thing. One minute you're alive, there's a whole world around you, humming and jumping, people coming in and out, doors opening and closing, love and anger and the whole mess of it all, and then like that, it's all gone. (CRYING) This is it Mark, only a few hours left of this until an eternity of nothingness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wheels in Mark's head are spinning again. Suddenly th heart monitor starts beating rapidly and Martha lurches i pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark immediately slams on the big red "call nurse" button holding his grandmother down as she lurches in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seconds later three nurses burst into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's seizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse #2 begins filling a syringe. Mark sits by his grandmother's head, they're both looking right at each ot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen closely to me, Grandma. I have a surprise for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We focus on Mark and his grandmother, inches from one ano as the paramedics busy themselves around Martha's dying b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're wrong about what happens when you die. It's not an eternity of nothingness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha is hanging on to every word Mark is saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you die you're going to go to your favorite place in the whole world. And you're going to be with all of the people you've ever loved and who have ever loved you. And you're going to be young again, and you'll be able to run through the fields and dance and jump, and there will be no sadness, no pain, just love and laughing and happiness. There will be ponies made of gold, and everyone will live in giant mansions, and everything will smell like cookies. And it will last for an eternity, Grandma. An eternity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears are rolling down Martha's face as a glimmering smil overtakes her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks up to see the nurses, paramedics and doctors a staring at Mark in total shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else happens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cardiogram flat lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do your jobs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone distractedly goes back to helping the grandmothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to be happy forever, grandma. I promise you. Say hello to my mom for me. Tell her I love her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, everyone has stopped helping Martha, they're all listening intently. Some of them are crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (TEARFULLY) I'm going to see my mother again when I die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us more, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Martha stops breathing. The machine flatlines. And with t Martha is gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark turns away from his grandmother. Standing outside in hallway is Jennifer, watching Mark with true empathy in h eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer pull up in front of Jennifer's apartmen There is a long beat of silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I just did something bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to come inside?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer sit side-by-side on her couch. Mark hol can of beer in his hand, gently turning it around in his palm, staring down at it vacantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer sadly watches Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly and almost absentmindedly, Jennifer's hand moves o and rests gently upon Mark's wrist, settling there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hold on them for a long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer have fallen asleep in the exact same position, both of them sitting side-by-side no the couch, hand still on his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark opens his eyes and looks down at her hand, then up a Jennifer who slowly opens her eyes and smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They share a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bleary eyed Mark drives home from Jennifer's. As he tur onto his street he finds hundreds of cars blocking the wa massive crowd of people are leaving their cars and walkin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gets out of his car to find a wild scene: hundreds o people camped out on the lawn of his apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing by his door is the NURSE from the hospital. She immediately points at Mark and screams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There he is!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is bum-rushed by a question-asking throng. All of th are pelting Mark with questions, all of them confused and hopeful and desperately looking for answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there only one place you go when you die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will everyone who has ever died be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this place called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will I get to have sex with people there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pushes through the crowd, overwhelmed by it all. He to his door and opens it, only to have the Nurse step in path and block the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe us an explanation. If you know something this important, you better tell us all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The words you spoke last night, to your grandmother, spread like wildfire. Please, tell us more. Explain what you said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, fine, just give me a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark pushes past her and into his building, closing the d behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark goes to his fridge and pulls out a beer. His mind is reeling. As he opens a drawer to get a bottle opener he s the letter: "MY INVENTION". Mark eyes it ominously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone rings. Mark screens the call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaving message) You've been gone for twenty minutes and I turn on the T.V to see you on every station. What's going on? This is seriously the weirdest thing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark picks up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember last night when I said I think I did something bad? Well now I know I did something bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're saying that you know something different about what happens after you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark walks into his bedroom and turns on the TV. Sure eno there's a newscaster on his lawn, giving a report, with a banner on the screen that reads, "New Death Discoveries".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark puts down the phone and listens to the T.V.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-four hours ago, Mark Bellison was just your typical nobody writer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTER (ON T.V) (cont'd) Today, people are saying he knows new information about what happens after you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark puts the phone to his ear again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, what do you know? What did you tell your grandmother last night? What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't explain it all right now. Why don't you come over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer pushes through the throng of people, which is no even larger than before. As she reaches the door Mark ope it for her and slides her through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come up quick, they look like they could get out of hand any second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hurries Jennifer into the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer sits on the couch while Mark, agitated beyond recognition, paces the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me what you told your grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think I should. Who knows what could happen next? I'm just going to keep my mouth shut from now on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you said obviously affected a lot of people. I don't think you have the choice to keep it in now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do. I could just walk out that door and get on a plane and go to Namibia. No one knows me in Namibia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell me what you said. Please, Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My grandmother was dying, and she was terrified, shaking all over. She didn't want to just become nothingness. So I told her that when she died there wouldn't be nothingness. That she would be with all of the people she loved who had died and that she would live an eternity of joy and happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer's heart skips a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barely able to speak) How do you know these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sighs and looks out the window. The crowd extends do the block, all of them sitting calmly on his lawn, talkin quietly to each other, trying to make sense of it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer gets up and stands beside Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to tell them everything you know. This is too big. You have no choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you don't understand. The words I said... they weren't... it's not right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did your grandmother feel when you told her these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy. At peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how did that make you feel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sweeping her hand over the crowd) Think how good it will feel to do the same for all of these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. But I need a few hours to get my thoughts together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go tell them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Are you sure this is right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is. You know something that's going to change mankind forever. It's the most important thing the world has ever heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer leaves the room. Mark, alone with his thoughts, down at his kitchen table, pulls out a few sheets of pape grabs a pen and starts writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark's neighborhood is a sea of candles. The crowd has gr beyond measure. A massive sea of people, all holding cand all waiting quietly like serene cows for Mark to come dow and make his announcement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is hunched over his table writing. There's a knock a the front door. Greg walks in with a large pizza and beer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought pizza. How come you never told me we all get mansions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer comes out of the bedroom and quickly "shhh's" Gr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inventing the bicycle is one thing, but this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. Let him work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer pulls Greg away from Mark. Mark goes back to wor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark puts down his pencil and places both written sheets to each other. He has finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark opens the door. Jennifer and Greg are on his bed watching T.V. The same newscaster stands outside the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In Seoul Korea, they wait. In Rome, Italy, they wait. In London, England, they wait. In New York City, they wait. The world has come to a standstill, everyone at their televisions and radios, or here on this lawn, waiting for Mark Bellison to come forth and tell the people what he knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark waves his manuscript in the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer and Greg jumps off the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They head towards the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel like I should be reading these off of something other than just notebook paper. I wish they were like, written on large tablets or even just nicer paper or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg grabs an empty pizza box off of the counter, rips it into two pieces and tapes his two pages onto them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark holds the two halves of the pizza boxes awkwardly an nods his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feels better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks at Jennifer and Greg with fear in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just tell them what you know

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck out there, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OTS of Newscaster cameraman. The newscaster is interviewi young man, with Mark's apartment building in the backgrou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard that he said we all get mansions, and that there's even ponies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to cameraman) Ponies. Mansions. Ice Cream. These are the things we can all expect when we die. What else can we expect? We won't know until Mark Bellison steps out of that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SHOUTING) THERE HE IS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark cracks open the front door and steps out onto his fr steps, with Jennifer right behind him. The newscaster and cameraman run to get into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks out at the sea of people staring silently at h waiting for answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man runs up and hands Mark a microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His voice echoes through the neighborhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could hear a pin drop. No one is even breathing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So. I guess you've all heard the things I told my grandmother last night and... I understand why you're here. (PAUSE) I know... some things. Some very important things. And I'm going to share these things with you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intercut throughout: different video feeds, people listen to radios, standing in the cold watching TV's through sto windows -- all around the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes a deep breath and holds up his "pizza box commandments".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything you want to know is written here. On this old pizza box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks out at the crowd, all of them so hopeful, so needy. Mark looks back at Jennifer and Greg who give him proud nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) Number one: There is a man who lives in the sky who controls everything. Number two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting; shouting) Whoa, whoa whoa. What does he look like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark wasn't prepared for questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (STRUGGLING) Tall. Big hands. A good head of hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ethnicity is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making it up as he goes) He's a new ethnicity. It's like a mix of all of our ethnicities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he live on a cloud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we see him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (becoming confident) No. He lives much higher than the clouds, too high to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he lives in space?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not that high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you mean the Thermosphere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, people I got a lot to get through here. I'm just telling you what I know: Man. Lives in the sky. You can't see him. Controls everything. Cool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number two: When you die you don't disappear into an eternity of nothingness. Instead, you go to a really great place. (PAUSE) Number three: In that place every person will get a mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of mansion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Whatever kind of mansion you're thinking of right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no! I wasn't thinking of a mansion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people echo this sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit! I was thinking of a horrible mansion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, it's the best mansion you can think of, not just now, but ever. Whatever the best mansion for you can possibly be, that's the one you'll get. (CONTINUING) Number four: When you die, all the people you love will be there too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will they have their own mansions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Everyone gets a mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I want them to live in my mansion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If they want to live with you, they can leave their mansion and live in yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens to their mansion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, it goes back on the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the people I hate? Will they be there too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN #4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, they're probably there, but you'll never see them. They're far off, too far for you to get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN #4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if they try to find me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't. They hate you too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN #4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what if they don't? What if they love me but I hate them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then you're just... you'll both be fine with it. There's only love there, okay? (CONTINUING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number five: When you die there will be free ice cream. All day. All night. Whatever flavor you can think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN #5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, even bad flavors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But why would you eat bad flavors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN #5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you just said every flavor I can think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAN #8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, I just thought about vanilla and skunks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't eat it then!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WOMAN #6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've just thought the chocolate sauce is diarrhea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't put it on then! What's wrong with you people? I mean... (CONTINUING) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK (cont'd) Number six: If you do bad things you won't get to go to this great place when you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will you go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A terrible place. The worst place imaginable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A rumble of terror moves through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What constitutes a bad thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Murder. Crime. Rape. Things like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to tell us all the things or else we might do them and it wouldn't be our fault!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole crowd echoes this sentiment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is punching someone bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if they're trying to hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is cursing bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about being late for work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine too. I mean, you might lose your job if your boss doesn't like it, but it won't effect what happens after you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about if you forget to feed your dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That also is fine. Unless the dog dies. Then it's bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you do just one bad thing do you go to the bad place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You get... (thinking about it) ... three chances. If you do three bad things you're out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like baseball!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a hubbub throughout the crowd: "It's like basebal "I love baseball" "I'm scared of the bad place".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any more?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About fifty people stand up and ask their questions at th same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, can we just move on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! We have to know everything that's bad!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. Let's start with you... (POINTING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it bad to wear pants?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. There's no hairstyle that will put you in the bad place. Like I've told you, the main things are hurting people physically on purpose, taking people's stuff, doing things to people they don't want done, killing people on purpose. Okay? Are we good?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd nods apprehensively. Many of the people in the crowd are crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the crying men, shaking like a leaf, stands up, wi terror in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SHAMEFUL) I've done many of those bad things. Is there anything I can do to not go to the bad place? Help me, I'm so scared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you didn't know about these bad things until I told you just now so you're fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CRYING) Am I fine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CRYING) What about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tons of people shout similar sentiments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all fine! I'm only talking about people who do bad things starting right now. Everyone else is fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd erupts in a massive cheer. People hug each othe passionately, wiping tears from their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (READING) Number seven: The man in the sky who controls everything decides if you go to the good place or the bad place. He also decides who lives and who dies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he cause natural disasters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he cause my mom to get cancer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he cause that tree to land on my car last week?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is quiet for a long beat....they're mulling thi over. The first man to speak is a blue collar guy with a thick Brooklyn accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say fuck the guy that lives in the sky!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole crowd erupts in agreement. People stand up shouting, flicking off the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! That guy's a fucking asshole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That motherfucker better hope I never see him face to face!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That guy's a fucking coward! Hiding up there and doing bad shit to us! Why doesn't he do it to our faces?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to stop that motherfucker before he kills us all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks worried. He didn't anticipate this. Suddenly a thought occurs to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (SHOUTING) WAIT!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy who lives in the sky and controls everything is also responsible for all the good stuff that happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole crowd "aaaahhs".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the guy who saved my life on that fishing trip when the boat capsized?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did he capsize the boat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the one who killed my grandmother and left me those millions of dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You betcha.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So is he the same one who cured my mom's cancer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd thinks this over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he's kind of a good guy, but he's also kind of a prick too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. But check this out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number eight: Even if the man in the sky does bad shit to you, he makes it up to you by giving you an eternity of good stuff after you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd "aaahhs" again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as you don't do any of the bad stuff you listed, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's kind of a test?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Right. (PAUSE) Well, that's it. That's everything I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks out at the crowd, they're all exhausted, their minds completely blown. The Nurse who started this all st forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know these things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (THINKING) The man in the clouds told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but how come we're just learning these things now, millions of years into our existence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, he forgot or something. I gotta go people, good night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark takes Jennifer by the hand and pulls her back inside building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, Jennifer and Greg wait for the elevator, all of the exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think that went well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open and they get inside. All three of them sta ahead, Mark looking exhausted, Jennifer and Greg with the minds completely blown... as the doors close and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spinning magazines and newspaper headlines proclaim "Mans for Everyone (almost)", "NASA searching for Man in the Sk "Finally -- A Reason to Do Good", "Time: Man of the Year: Mark Bellison", "Mansion Prices Plummet Worldwide", "Cult Bellison Await Further Answers", "Man in Sky Murders fort two in Earthquake", "Man in Sky Continues to Give AIDS to Babies", "Workplace Productivity down Fourteen Percent -- Everyone Daydreaming About Mansions".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark is at Lecture Films turning in the script for "The B Plague" to Anthony. Rob gives Mark a dirty look as he pas him in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, smiling proudly, stands behind the camera while Nat Goldfrappe reads his script. In the background are Jennif and Greg, hanging out on set. Jennifer can be seen chatti with Rob by craft services.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark removes the "For Sale" sign from the front yard of a brand new, beautiful home. Jennifer and Greg congratulate Mark enthusiastically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer are walking down the street together wh Mark stops to point out a new building with a sign that reads, "A Quiet Place To Think About the Man in the Sky". building boasts a large stained glass window portraying M holding the two halves of the pizza box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, Jennifer and Greg laugh it up in a stretch limousin it pulls up to the movie premier of "The Black Plague".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, Jennifer and Greg walk the red carpet at the premie "The Black Plague". Mark is the center of attention. Rob stops by on the red carpet to say hello to Jennifer and whisper something into her ear. Jennifer laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Jennifer have dinner together, the best of frien but as they cheers their champagne glasses there is a tin of sadness in Mark's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A disheveled Mark, unshaven and sloppy looking, sits in a reclining chair, wearing boxers and a bathrobe, drinking beer. Beer cans are littered everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young gay man in a suit stands before him with a pad an pen writing down everything Mark says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So then the flying duck flew all the way to Alaska where it met up with a polar bear who could talk. And the polar bear's name was Martin. And the polar bear was wearing a green cape. And Martin and the flying duck both had race cars with their names printed on the side and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer enters the room, upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw three people climbing the fence into your backyard. You really need to think about getting better security. (noticing beer cans

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, how many of those have you had?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer grabs the beer out of Mark's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; glaring at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then the evil goblin witch came in and stole the flying duck's race car and made the flying duck very angry. (grabbing at his beer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK (cont'd) Luckily the Polar Bear was there to snatch the race car back... (But he misses) Unfortunately, the witch was a smart witch and the polar bear was powerless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that the end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a strange ending.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, don't look at me: it's the Man in the Sky's story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to take this over to Lecture Films?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Tell them to shoot that one this week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assistant walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (YELLING) Tell them it's for kids!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer glares at Mark, disappointed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't left the house in weeks. Every time I come by you're just sitting here writing down stories you get from the Man in the Sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he's the boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think you should go outside sometime? You know there's about five thousand people on our lawn waiting to ask you questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with you? You seem sad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it. You're a very successful writer, you've won countless awards and Oscars...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer waves towards a shelf full of Oscars and various other awards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've changed the way people see the world, the way they see death and life. You've made the entire world happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not the entire world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Not you. The one person who should be happy, the person who has everything...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (INTERRUPTING) Not everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits up in his chair and looks right at Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd trade it all in for you. All of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer sighs and sits down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you've got me. As a friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not sarcastic) Yeah. That's important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARK (cont'd) But why can't we be together. Why can't you be with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because of the whole snub nosed thing. With kids, your genetics. You know, fat, short...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stopping her) Yeah. Okay. Yup. (PAUSE) It's almost a shame that being rich and powerful and famous doesn't change your genetics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be great if it changed your genetic material because I really love you but I just don't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly Mark has an idea. He looks right at Jennifer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does change your genetics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at her for a short beat. He can't go through it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, it doesn't. Our kids would be short and fat with little snub noses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Too bad. (PAUSE) Anyway, I've come to tell you I can't go to the movies with you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? With who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob Marlowe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to be fucking... Rob Marlowe?!? He's a complete and total asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not to me. He's very sweet and kind to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well of course he is, look at you. I mean, for fuck's sake, a shark would be nice to you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well no, I mean... (PAUSE) Don't go out with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? He's a great match for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he got that I don't?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We talked about this. If you and I got together it wouldn't be fair to our kids. They have the right to be attractive and have good genes. (PAUSE) If Rob and I get married You can move into our mansion with us when we all die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to move into your fucking mansion. And what are you doing thinking about marriage with him already? You haven't even gone on one date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like nothing's changed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of things have changed. I wish you could be happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a knock at the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him. Gotta go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's picking you up here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was his idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stands up, in shock and follows Jennifer to the fron door. She opens the door to find Rob looking handsome and arrogant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up? Wow, I can't wait to have sex with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob notices Mark in his boxers and a bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh hey there, Mark. You look like trash. (to Jennifer) Come on Jennifer, let's go have some fun. And then have some sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jennifer turns back to Mark, sad that he's upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll call you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes and Mark is left standing there alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg, dressed in a bathrobe and looking even more slovenl than Mark, waddles up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg are shit-faced, sitting around Mark's giant swimming pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, watch this. (yelling over the fence) HEY PEOPLE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About forty voices shout back: "He's talking to us!" "May he has more answers!" "Finally!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man in the sky just told me something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark snickers to himself. Greg, drunk and stupid, can't h but snicker too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're all gay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg explode laughing. From the other side of th fence we can hear people mumbling shock. "I am gay." "I always knew it." "This is going to be awkward for my husband."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And adopted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark and Greg almost roll into the pool they're laughing hard. The people on the other side of the fence aren't laughing: "Who's my real mother?", "This explains so much "Dad, why didn't you tell me?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why we're laughing. It's really probably very sad for those people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gettin' a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hobbles up and walks into the house. Moments later h emerges with two cokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of beer. Just Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark tosses Greg a Coke and sits down on his chaise loung cracking open his Coke and taking a sip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to do something big again. Like telling the people what happens when they die. That felt good. I gotta do something big like that again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the Man in the Sky will tell you something new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks down at his can of Coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON COKE CAN: The warning label is extremely long an written in very small type. It starts with, "COKE IS VERY FOR YOU. The following are diseases, physical ailments an general health issues that coke might cause:"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The label then goes on to list dozens of ailments. Mark's eyes scan down to the very bottom of the label where it s simply, "If you still want to drink Coke, do so at your o risk."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark looks over to find Greg staring at the depressing la as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh, this shit is so bad for you. I really shouldn't drink this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark stares at this label for a moment, thinking. With hi hand he covers everything on the label except for "Please Enjoy Coke."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles widely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Greg. What if I told you that drinking Coke was good for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg turns to him, his face full of hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And not just Coke. But all the delicious foods you're not supposed to eat. What if they were all of a sudden really, really good for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would be the happiest day of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen high powered executives from all over the globe s around a massive board room table. The head seat at the t is unoccupied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They mumble back and forth to each other, unsure why they there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark bursts into the room in a suit, looking very manicur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentleman, thank you all for coming here on such short notice. I have some very big news for you all today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it from the Man in the Sky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nope, this one I came up with all on my own. And it's going to change the way you all do business... forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark hits a button and a projection screen comes down on far wall. Mark starts a slide show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up until now, all products sold worldwide have warning labels printed on them. Warnings like these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF SLIDES: We see the same warning we just saw on Coke can, a commercial jet with "This Plane Might Crash - Four Of Our Other Ones Did" printed on its side, a car dashboard light reading "This Car will Ignite Upon Impact Always", and a sticker on a grocery store package of grou meat that reads "Injected with hormones that make it tast better -- but will eventually give you cancer".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you can see, a lot of these products can be very depressing. They remind people of all the horrible things that can happen to them in life. People hate thinking about horrible things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but they have to know those things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXECUTIVE #2 (cont'd) They have to be able to protect themselves. I don't want to hurt anyone. Especially now that I know about the "bad place".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the room shudders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear me out, fellas. Allow me to introduce you to the future of your companies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark changes the slide to a can of coke that simple reads "Coke -- Tastes Great! And It's Good For You!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone in the room "ahhhs".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where can I get some of that healthy coke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the same Coke as before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The executives all squint their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this one is healthy! And it tastes great!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have any samples?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys, it's the same Coke on the inside. I've just changed the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (REVELATION) Somehow by changing the outside, he's also changed the inside!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone "aaahs" in understanding. Mark sighs and changes slide to that of a commercial airliner with the words "Completely Safe" writing on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank goodness. I've always hated flying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What an invention! How did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything, guys. I made this on my computer last night. The plane is exactly the same as it was before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody in the room gets it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the only plane I'll ever fly on again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the point here guys. With these new advertising strategies, people will buy your products with abandon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it will take years to replace all of our stock with these new improved products you've invented.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. It won't. All you have to do is print these words on the packaging. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark changes the slide again: The car dashboard light now reads, "This Car Prevents Crashes", and another slide tha shows a package of meat with a sticker reading, "This Mea Actually Cures Cancer".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even if you don't understand it, just start shipping these products out to people as you see them here and you're all going to get very, very rich.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, they're still the same products you have on the shelves right now. The only difference now is that people won't get bummed out or scared when they use them. Isn't that a good thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The executives all nod their heads in agreement and rise shake Mark's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentleman, if you'll excuse me, I have five thousand gay orphans on my front lawn that are going bananas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a suburban housewife as she pushes her shopping cart through the aisles of a bright and shiny super marke

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She picks up a six pack of Coke and notices the label: "N Coke -- It Tastes Great! And it's Good For You!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The housewife smiles widely and enthusiastically tosses i her cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SERIES OF CUTS: The housewife grabbing different products marveling at the new, improved features: "Cures Sadness!" "Tastes Better than Real Chicken!", "This Candy is All Yo Body Needs To Survive!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a full cart the housewife wheels it to the checkout counter to find swarms of people already there, all of th carts bursting to the brim with new, exciting products.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks excited and happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back at his old stomping ground, Mark sits at the bar by himself drinking coffee and watching the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg sits next to him, with two boxes of cookies and a li of coke in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different newspapers are spread out on the bar, all of th with similar headlines, "World Rocked By New Healthy Products", "People Everywhere Line up for Guilt-Free Trea "YOU CAN EAT CAKE -- ALL THE TIME!".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ANGLE ON TV: A FAT MAN is being interviewed in front of a super market, he holds a bag full of junk food in front o him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank the Man in the Sky for this. I've never been happier in my life. Now I can eat whatever I want, whenever I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man takes a bite of a Twinkie and wavers a bit like h going to pass out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man steadies himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I must just be real happy. It says on the wrapper that they help boost your happiness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man smiles, but he's obviously not feeling well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's watching the TV with a bit of worry on his face. He turns to Greg who is eating a stack of cookies and washin down by gulping from a liter of coke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should slow down there, Greg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because the package says it's not bad for you doesn't mean you have to gorge yourself on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it tastes so good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg shoves three more cookies into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg holds up the package of cookies and points to the disclaimer which reads, "These cookies make you smarter".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look sad. Here, have a brownie. They'll cheer you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greg hands Mark a brownie that, sure enough, says "They'l cheer you up!" right on the package.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish that worked for me, Greg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nevermind. I'll see you around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark gets up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark drives while we take in a bit of his world, highligh the various changes he's wrought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homeless man stands on the street corner with a sign th now reads, "Screw it. I'll be in my mansion soon." He has big smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The same business man pulls up beside Mark's car, this ti eating a giant donut and talking loudly into his cell pho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to anyone on my cell phone. But from a distance I look very important and busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a red light Mark eavesdrops on the same arguing couple

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I won't move into your mansion with you when we die. You're really smothering me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The more you push me away, the more attracted I am to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bus passes in front of Mark's car. The ad now reads, "Pepsi. Just As Good as Coke."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A car honks behind Mark. The man leans out of his car and yells at Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it, fatty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
